There are many ethical theories and schools of thought which all go about morality and immorality differently. One thing may be believed moral by one person, while the exact opposite may be believed by someone else. Of course, beliefs don't necessarily reflect objective reality. It could be that there is no morality, and so each person or culture basically gets to decide what they think is immoral (and so it is), or else it could be that most people (if not all) are simply mistaken about the truth of morality (and in that case, we do not, and possibly cannot, know for sure what true immorality is). That said, nearly all (other than maybe the occasional radical ethical nihilist/relativist/egoist theory) would assert the belief that harming innocents (when it cannot be reasonably expected to help an even greater number of other innocent people, as with Utilitarianism and other forms of consequentialism) is absolutely forbibben by morality/natural law. This seems to match most people’s gut feeling about the act of murder. It is thus believed, if approached from a place of reason and a belief in the inherent value and worth of other human minds, that to murder someone without either a benevolent intent (as in expected/subjective consequentialism) or effect (as in actual/objective consequentialism), is always immoral, or morally wrong.
